categories.name: Kashmir Shaivism Sanskrit: Words, Meanings & Translations
categories.description: Master key Sanskrit terms in Kashmir Shaivism with accurate meanings, context, and English translations.

subcategories.name: Core Concepts & Deities
subcategories.description: Learn foundational Sanskrit words representing the essence and deities of Kashmir Shaivism.

subcategories.name: Philosophical & Technical Terms
subcategories.description: Understand advanced philosophical terms describing metaphysics, consciousness, and realization.

questions.question: Translate 'Śiva' in Kashmir Shaivism.
questions.explanation: In Kashmir Shaivism, Śiva represents the absolute, unchanging awareness that underlies all experience.

questions.question: What is the Sanskrit word for 'Divine Energy' inseparable from Śiva?
questions.explanation: Śakti is the creative, expressive power of Śiva—consciousness in motion.

questions.question: Meaning of 'Spanda'?
questions.explanation: Spanda is the innate vibration within consciousness that creates all manifestation.

questions.question: Translate 'Prakāśa'.
questions.explanation: Prakāśa means the self-luminous light of consciousness—the radiance of Śiva.

questions.question: Translate 'Vimarśa'.
questions.explanation: Vimarśa is consciousness’s power to know itself. It’s the self-reflexive aspect of awareness.

questions.question: Meaning of 'Paramaśiva'?
questions.explanation: Paramaśiva is the transcendent essence—pure being beyond thought or differentiation.

questions.question: Translate 'Cit' (चित्).
questions.hint: Awareness itself, not the contents of awareness.
questions.explanation: Cit is the pure, all-pervading awareness present in every experience.

questions.question: Meaning of 'Ānanda'?
questions.explanation: Ānanda is the bliss that naturally arises from pure consciousness, not dependent on external conditions.

questions.question: Translate 'Icchā Śakti'.
questions.explanation: Icchā Śakti represents divine desire—the will of consciousness to manifest itself.

questions.question: Translate 'Kriyā Śakti'.
questions.explanation: Kriyā Śakti is the power that brings consciousness’s intention into material expression.

questions.question: Translate 'Jñāna Śakti'.
questions.explanation: Jñāna Śakti reveals divine wisdom—consciousness knowing itself and its creation.

questions.question: Translate 'Aham' (अहम्).
questions.explanation: Aham is the primordial 'I' from which self-awareness and all differentiation emerge.

questions.question: Meaning of 'Śūnya'?
questions.explanation: Śūnya represents the dynamic void—pregnant with potential rather than mere absence.

questions.question: Translate 'Sadāśiva'.
questions.explanation: Sadāśiva is the stage where awareness recognizes its own reflection within creation.

questions.question: Meaning of 'Anuttara'?
questions.explanation: Anuttara is the supreme state beyond all duality—ultimate consciousness as both immanent and transcendent.

questions.question: Translate 'Upāya'.
questions.explanation: Upāya refers to a spiritual method. Kashmir Shaivism teaches four—Āṇava, Śākta, Śāmbhava, and Anupāya.

questions.question: Meaning of 'Āṇava Upāya'?
questions.correctAnswer: Path of Effort or Individual Discipline
questions.hint: Practice relying on the limited self.
questions.explanation: Āṇava Upāya includes physical and mental techniques for concentration, suited for beginners.

questions.question: Translate 'Śākta Upāya'.
questions.explanation: Śākta Upāya uses awareness of thought and emotion to recognize divine consciousness within experience.

questions.question: Meaning of 'Śāmbhava Upāya'?
questions.explanation: Śāmbhava Upāya is direct recognition—awareness awakening to itself without technique.

questions.question: Translate 'Anupāya'.
questions.explanation: Anupāya is spontaneous awakening—when nothing needs to be done for realization.

questions.question: Meaning of 'Pratyabhijñā'?
questions.explanation: Pratyabhijñā doctrine teaches liberation through recognizing one’s nature as divine consciousness.

questions.question: Translate 'Mokṣa'.
questions.explanation: Mokṣa is realizing you were never bound—awakening to the truth of your divine nature.

questions.question: Translate 'Malas'.
questions.explanation: Malas are the coverings (āṇava, māyīya, kārma) that restrict perception of our divine self.

questions.question: Meaning of 'Āṇava Mala'?
questions.explanation: Āṇava Mala causes the sense of individual incompleteness or ego-based limitation.

questions.question: Meaning of 'Māyīya Mala'?
questions.explanation: Māyīya Mala makes the one consciousness appear as many distinct entities.

questions.question: Translate 'Kārma Mala'.
questions.explanation: Kārma Mala binds beings through identification with personal actions and their fruits.

questions.question: Translate 'Tattva'.
questions.explanation: The 36 Tattvas outline the process from pure consciousness to material manifestation.

questions.question: Meaning of 'Śiva-Śakti Aikya'?
questions.hint: No separation between stillness and motion.
questions.explanation: Śiva-Śakti Aikya expresses the inseparability of consciousness and its creative energy.

questions.question: Translate 'Caitanya'.
questions.explanation: Caitanya is pure, living awareness—the essence that animates the universe.

questions.question: Meaning of 'Samvit'?
questions.explanation: Samvit is unbounded, self-aware consciousness—identical with Śiva itself.
